questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 1 year ago. His only medication is metformin. His serum glucose is 186 mg/dL and his hemoglobin A1c is 7.6%. The physician prescribes an additional antidiabetic drug and counsels the patient on its delayed onset of action. At a follow-up appointment 4 weeks later, the patient reports that his home blood glucose readings have improved. He also mentions that he has had a weight gain of 4 kg (8.8 lb). The patient has most likely been treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, which blocks the reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule. It has an early onset of action and promotes weight loss rather than weight gain. Other adverse effects associated with empagliflozin include hyperkalemia (unknown mechanism) and chronic glucosuria, resulting in urinary tract infections, vaginal yeast infections, and polyuria with dehydration.

B) INCORRECT:

Liraglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, increases glucose-dependent insulin secretion. It has an early onset of action and promotes weight loss rather than weight gain because it delays gastric emptying and increases satiety. Adverse effects of this drug are gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting) and pancreatitis.

C) CORRECT:

Thiazolidinediones, such as rosiglitazone and pioglitazone, activate the transcription factor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ). Activation of PPAR-γ improves insulin sensitivity over several weeks by upregulating the transcription of adiponectin and GLUT4 glucose transporters in adipose and muscle cells. It causes weight gain, as seen in this patient, in addition to other adverse effects, such as fluid retention, exacerbation of congestive heart failure, and osteoporosis.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

D) INCORRECT:

Glyburide, which is a second-generation sulfonylurea, induces insulin release from beta cells and may lead to weight gain. Unlike the drug prescribed to this patient, however, glyburide typically has an early onset of action with serum insulin levels increasing 15–60 minutes after a single dose. Further adverse effects of this drug include life-threatening hypoglycemia, and allergic skin reactions.

E) INCORRECT:

Sitagliptin, which is a DPP-4 inhibitor, increases the level of GLP-1 and promotes glucose-dependent insulin secretion. It has an early onset of action and is not associated with weight gain. Adverse effects of this drug include upper respiratory tract infections and pancreatitis.
questions.hint: The drug that has been added to the patient's medication regimen has a delayed onset of action because it acts at the level of transcription.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well but is unhappy about being overweight. She reports that she feels out of breath when walking for more than one block and while climbing stairs. She has tried to lose weight for several years without success. She goes for a walk 3 times a week but she has difficulty following a low-calorie diet. During the past 12 months, she has had two urinary tract infections that were treated with fosfomycin. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis. Her only current medication is metformin. She has never smoked. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows cracking in both knees on passive movement. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show an HbA1c of 9.5%, and a fasting serum glucose concentration of 158 mg/dL. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

GLP-1 agonists, such as exenatide, can cause weight loss and control hyperglycemia. Incretin-based therapeutic agents such as GLP-1 agonists also have the additional benefit of a low risk of medication-induced hypoglycemia. Besides metformin and GLP-1 agonists, other drugs that can be used for weight loss in diabetic patients include SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin), orlistat, and pramlintide. However, SGLT-2 inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections, as is the case here. Also, orlistat does not cause glycemic control, which is desired in this patient, and pramlintide is only used in combination with insulin therapy.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

B) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione known to cause weight gain, both directly and due to fluid retention and edema, making this treatment inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Glyburide is a sulfonylurea, which is known to cause weight gain. The need for weight loss in this patient makes this drug undesirable. Moreover, in patients older than 65 years, the use of sulfonylureas with biguanides such as metformin is associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Acarbose, an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, is not associated with weight loss and is therefore not indicated in the management of this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

While dapagliflozin can be used for weight loss in diabetic patients, it is contraindicated in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections (as is the case here) because the glycosuric effect of SGLT-2 inhibitors creates a favorable environment for bacterial colonization of the urinary tract.

F) INCORRECT:

Phentermine is an appetite suppressant and can therefore cause weight loss. However, phentermine monotherapy is not used for the management of diabetes mellitus because it does not control hyperglycemia.

G) INCORRECT:

Saxagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, can be used as an adjunct to metformin in patients with poor glycemic control. However, it does not cause weight loss. Moreover, the glucose-lowering capacity of DPP-4 inhibitors is not as good as some of the other classes of antidiabetic medications. Since this patient has a very high HbA1C of 9.5%, a drug that offers greater glycemic control is needed.
questions.hint: This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, and a hemoglobin A1c of 9.5%, both of which suggest insufficient glycemic control with her current medication regimen. The patient's desire to lose weight should also be considered when adjusting her treatment.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of increasing shortness of breath and ankle swelling. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and congestive heart failure. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/59 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. There are jugular venous pulsations 5 cm above the sternal angle. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. There is edema from the mid-tibia to the ankle bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7100/mm3



Serum



 Na+

129 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 K+

4.8 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen

48 mg/dL


 Glucose
196 mg/dL


 Creatinine

2.1 mg/dL


In addition to administration of a loop diuretic, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Metformin is associated with an increased risk of life-threatening lactic acidosis in patients with predisposing conditions that reduce lactic acid clearance (i.e., renal and/or hepatic insufficiency), increased lactic acid production (e.g., sepsis), or a combination of both (e.g., heart failure with low cardiac output). This patient's renal insufficiency and HF with decreased cardiac output are both contraindications to metformin therapy, which should therefore be discontinued immediately. Insulin should instead be used for inpatient glycemic control.

The use of metformin may be safe in the case of chronic HF with preserved cardiac output. Other important indications for discontinuing metformin (albeit temporarily) are surgery, acidemia, and the intravenous administration of an iodinated contrast medium (e.g., CT scans, fluoroscopic studies).
Image Description:

Schematic illustration of situations in which different antidiabetic substance classes should be preferred or avoided

Eligible substance classes for the treatment of type 2 diabetes are insulin, metformin, sulfonylureas (SU), SGLT-2 inhibitors (SGLT-2-I), dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP-4-I), glucagon-like-peptide-1 agonists (GLP-1-RA), alpha-glucosidase inhibitors (AGI), and thiazolidinedione (TZD). TZDs are greyed out as some substances are currently not available in the EU and should be used less commonly due to safety concerns.

B) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is commonly used in the empiric treatment of suspected MRSA infections. However, in the absence of fever and leukocytosis, this patient's respiratory symptoms are more consistent with pulmonary edema secondary to acutely decompensated heart failure than an infectious etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient takes aspirin for his coronary artery disease, which requires low-dose aspirin. While potentially nephrotoxic agents, including NSAIDs and high-dose aspirin, should be avoided in patients with AKI, low-dose aspirin does not impair renal perfusion and should therefore be continued in this patient to prevent complications of his illness.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with ADHF, the use of vasodilatory medications such as nitroprusside can be considered as an adjunct to diuretic therapy for dyspnea relief. However, nitroprusside should not be used in patients with hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are used in patients with ADHF in order to treat fluid overload. However, loop diuretics are the first-line therapy in patients with ADHF. Thiazide diuretics are only used if loop diuretics fail to relieve congestion.

F) INCORRECT:

In a patient with ADHF, noninvasive mechanical ventilation such as CPAP can reduce the left ventricular afterload, alleviate work of breathing, increase diffusion of oxygen across the alveoli, and even decrease pulmonary edema. However, the benefits of mechanical ventilation can be outweighed by potential adverse effects, such as barotrauma (especially in chronic smokers), decreased right ventricular preload (due to decreased venous return), and even increased right ventricular afterload (due to increased pulmonary vascular resistance with high levels of positive airway pressure). For this reason, mechanical ventilation is only indicated for patients with persistent hypoxemia (< 90%) and/or a respiratory rate > 25/min despite O2 therapy.

G) INCORRECT:

Inotropic support should be considered in a patient with ADHF and hypotension. However, the inotrope of choice in patients with heart failure is dopamine. The use of norepinephrine should only be considered in patients with a systolic blood pressure < 70 mm Hg.
questions.hint: Acute worsening of dyspnea and pedal edema in this patient suggests acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). A blood pressure of 95/59 mm Hg in this scenario indicates a low cardiac output. His laboratory findings also indicate prerenal acute kidney injury (BUN:creatinine ratio > 20:1) secondary to heart failure (cardiorenal syndrome).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of gradually worsening fatigue, increased urinary frequency, and blurry vision for 5 months. He has not seen a doctor in several years. Physical examination shows decreased vibratory sense and proprioception in the lower extremities. His hemoglobin A1c is 10.4%. Treatment for his condition with an appropriate medication is begun. In response to this drug, pancreatic islet cells begin producing increasing amounts of secretory granules. The patient was most likely treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin (biguanide) exerts its action by enhancing the effects of insulin in two major ways. First, metformin decreases hepatic glucose output by inhibiting gluconeogenesis and intestinal glucose absorption. Second, the drug increases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues (such as muscle and liver). Even though metformin is often the preferred drug for T2DM because of its favorable risk-benefit ratio, it does not increase insulin secretion.

B) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, works by activating a transcription factor (PPARγ) to increase transcription of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism. These drugs benefit T2DM patients by reducing insulin resistance, not by increasing insulin secretion.

C) CORRECT:

Glimepiride, a sulfonylurea, stimulates insulin secretion from pancreatic β-cells. Their principle target is the ATP-sensitive K+ channels in the pancreatic β-cell plasma membrane. Inhibition of ATP-sensitive K+ channels by sulfonylureas causes depolarization of the β-cell membrane, leading to an influx of Ca2+, which stimulates exocytosis of insulin-containing secretory granules.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

D) INCORRECT:

Acarbose is used to treat T2DM, but it works by inhibiting intestinal brush border alpha-glucosidase (enzyme responsible for disaccharide breakdown), resulting in decreased intestinal glucose absorption. By reducing the rate of carbohydrate digestion, this drug is particularly effective in controlling postprandial blood glucose levels. It has no direct effect on insulin secretion.

E) INCORRECT:

Canagliflozin, a SGLT-2 inhibitor, blocks reabsorption of glucose from the kidney, resulting in increased urinary excretion of glucose. The subsequent glucosuria reduces plasma glucose concentrations. Canagliflozin does not increase insulin secretion.

F) INCORRECT:

Insulin may be indicated as initial treatment for some patients with T2DM, depending on the severity of their metabolic disturbance. However, insulin therapy simulates physiological glucose metabolism and modulates its absorption from the blood. Administering it does not increase endogenous insulin production.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms raise suspicion for diabetes mellitus, and the elevated HbA1c confirms this diagnosis. The secretory granules produced by the pancreatic islet cells in response to his new medication contain insulin and C-peptide, suggesting that the administered drug works by increasing endogenous insulin production.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue and increased thirst. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (160 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her fasting serum glucose concentration is 249 mg/dL. Treatment with an oral hypoglycemic agent is begun. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased glucagon release from pancreatic α cells is the mechanism of action of DPP-4 inhibitors and amylin analogs (e.g., pramlintide). These drugs do not cause weight loss and are not typically used as first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Metformin, the drug of choice for this patient, has been found to cause a slight increase in plasma glucagon levels while decreasing glucagon action.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased insulin secretion from pancreatic β cells via blockage of pancreatic potassium channels is the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas and meglitinides. These drugs are usually given as an adjunct treatment if monotherapy with metformin does not achieve the aimed HbA1c target. Since an effect of these drugs is weight gain, they are not recommended as first-line therapy in overweight patients. Metformin, the drug of choice for this patient, increases peripheral insulin sensitivity but it does not considerably affect insulin release.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased intestinal glucose absorption through inhibition of hydrolysis of disaccharides and complex carbohydrates (e.g., starch) is the mechanism of action of α-glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose). These drugs do not cause weight loss and are not typically used as first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Metformin, the drug of choice for this patient, does decrease intestinal glucose absorption by an incompletely understood mechanism (possibly related to decreased activity of intestinal GLUT2 transporters) but it does not decrease disaccharide hydrolysis.

D) INCORRECT:

An increase in renal glucose elimination by reversibly blocking glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubule of the kidney is the mechanism of action of sodium-dependent glucose transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors, e.g., dapagliflozin. Although these drugs cause weight loss, they are not typically used as first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Metformin, the drug of choice for this patient, does not increase renal glucose elimination.

E) CORRECT:

Biguanides such as metformin result in decreased hepatic gluconeogenesis via inhibition of the mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD). Furthermore, metformin improves insulin sensitivity, thereby increasing peripheral glucose uptake and utilization (↑ glycolysis), and also results in decreased intestinal glucose absorption. Side effects of metformin include lactic acidosis and gastrointestinal symptoms.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying
questions.hint: The first-line oral hypoglycemic drug in patients with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus is typically metformin. Metformin also has the added benefit of causing weight loss, which is desired in this overweight patient because weight loss decreases insulin resistance and improves glycemic control.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, the patient was started on metformin therapy after counseling on diet, exercise, and weight reduction failed to reduce his hyperglycemia. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin A1c is 8.4%. Pioglitazone is added to the patient's medication regimen. Which of the following cellular changes is most likely to occur in response to this new drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased breakdown of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) is the mechanism of action of dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (e.g., sitagliptin, saxagliptin). These agents increase the effect of incretins by blocking their breakdown in the intestinal lumen. This results in increased glucose-dependent insulin release, decreased glucagon secretion, and delayed gastric emptying. Decreased breakdown of GLP-1 is not expected in response to treatment with pioglitazone.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased sodium-dependent glucose cotransport is the mechanism of action of SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin). These agents affect the kidneys, blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the proximal renal tubules, which causes glycosuria and polyuria. This effect is not expected in response to treatment with pioglitazone.

C) INCORRECT:

Depolarization of pancreatic β-cells is the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide, glipizide) and meglitinides (e.g., nateglinide, repaglinide). These agents block the ATP-sensitive potassium channels, causing depolarization of the cell membrane, calcium influx, and insulin secretion. Sulfonylureas and meglitinides are referred to as secretagogues because they enhance insulin release. This effect is not expected in response to treatment with pioglitazone.

D) INCORRECT:

Autophosphorylation of receptor tyrosine kinase is the mechanism of action of insulin. Insulin increases glucose uptake for glycogen synthesis and storage in the liver and muscle. In addition, insulin increases triglyceride storage in adipose tissue. All of these mechanisms decrease serum glucose levels. Pioglitazone, however, does not act on receptor tyrosine kinases.

E) CORRECT:

Increased transcription of adipokines is part of the mechanism of action of thiazolidinediones (e.g., pioglitazone, rosiglitazone). These drugs work by activating PPAR-γ (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor of gamma type), which increases the transcription of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism. This leads to increased levels of adiponectin and other adipokines, which are decreased in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, and increased storage of triglycerides and subsequent reduction of products of lipid metabolism (e.g., free fatty acids) that otherwise enhance insulin resistance. This results in increased glucose utilization and reduced hepatic glucose production.

As a result of their action at the transcriptional level, the maximal glucose-lowering effect of thiazolidinediones may be delayed for several weeks.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying
questions.hint: Pioglitazone is an antidiabetic drug of the thiazolidinedione class that works by increasing glucose utilization and decreasing those products of lipid metabolism that enhance insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease. Current medications include metformin, aspirin, pravastatin, and losartan. Her body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin A1c concentration is 8%. She does not want to start insulin injection therapy and is afraid that a new medication is going to cause weight gain. Empagliflozin is added to her diabetes regimen. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects of this new drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced localized lipodystrophy, characterized by atrophy and sometimes hypertrophy of subcutaneous fat, is associated with subcutaneous insulin injections. However, with the availability of purified human insulin, this side effect is now rarely seen. Other medications, such as glucocorticoids and HIV antiretroviral drugs (i.e., zidovudine, protease inhibitors), can also cause lipodystrophy. Empagliflozin does not cause lipodystrophy.

B) CORRECT:

Inhibition of SGLT2 by empagliflozin increases urinary glucose concentrations, which subsequently predisposes patients to vaginal candidiasis and urinary tract infections. Because SGLT2 inhibitors are associated with acute kidney injury, patients taking these agents should undergo regular renal function testing, and their use is contraindicated in patients with severe renal impairment. Other effects of SGLT2 inhibitors include weight loss and (orthostatic) hypotension.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia may be seen with the use of sulfonylureas, meglitinides (although to a lesser degree than sulfonylureas), and insulin. Empagliflozin does cause glycosuria, but this rarely leads to hypoglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a rare complication of first-generation sulfonylurea use (chlorpropamide, tolbutamide) via an unknown mechanism. SGLT-2 inhibitors do not increase the risk of agranulocytosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactic acidosis is a rare complication associated with metformin therapy. Although this patient is on metformin, the addition of empagliflozin does not increase the risk of developing lactic acidosis. The highest risk of developing lactic acidosis with metformin use is seen in elderly patients and those with cardiac or renal impairment.

F) INCORRECT:

Thiazolidinediones (e.g., rosiglitazone) have been associated with an increased risk of fractures. Although early safety outcome studies suggested that canagliflozin also increases the risk of bone fractures, a meta-analysis of all trials found that empagliflozin and dapagliflozin do not.
questions.hint: Empagliflozin is a reversible inhibitor of sodium-dependent glucose co-transporters (SGLT2), which are located in the proximal convoluted tubules of the kidneys. Blockade of this receptor leads to decreased renal glucose reabsorption and increased urinary glucose excretion.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He reports that he has been adherent to his current antidiabetic medication regimen. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 8.5%. The physician prescribes a drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to this patient's medication regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase 4 inhibitor. Dipeptidyl peptidase 4, like alpha-glucosidase, is a membrane-bound enzyme that catalyzes chemical bond cleavage. However, DPP-4 hydrolyzes dipeptide bonds on polypeptides, not carbohydrates. Blocking DPP-4 prevents the breakdown of incretins, which leads to increased insulin release and improved glucose control.

B) INCORRECT:

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor. SGLT2 is a symporter that reabsorbs sodium and glucose from the glomerular filtrate; canagliflozin does not inhibit hydrolyzation of carbohydrate bonds.

C) INCORRECT:

Repaglinide is a meglitinide that inhibits potassium channels on pancreatic beta cells, which results in increased insulin secretion. Repaglinide does not inhibit hydrolyzation of carbohydrate bonds.

D) INCORRECT:

Pramlintide is an amylin analog that binds to G protein-coupled receptors and results in early satiety, delayed gastric emptying, and decreased glucagon secretion. Pramlintide does not inhibit hydrolyzation of carbohydrate bonds.

E) CORRECT:

Miglitol inhibits alpha-glucosidase and thus prevents the hydrolysis of polysaccharides to monosaccharides. Acarbose is the other alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that is available in the US. Since polysaccharides are not absorbed as easily as monosaccharides, alpha-glucosidase therapy results in a slower rise in postprandial blood glucose concentrations. Adverse effects of alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are caused by impaired absorption and include flatulence, diarrhea, and early satiety.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

F) INCORRECT:

Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that stimulates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ), which increases the transcription of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism to increase glucose utilization and decrease hepatic glucose production. Rosiglitazone does not inhibit hydrolyzation of carbohydrate bonds.
questions.hint: The drug targets alpha-glucosidase, a membrane-bound (brush-border) enzyme of the small intestine that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. His blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. His glomerular filtration rate is calculated to be 105 mL/min/1.73 m2 and glucose clearance is calculated to be 103 mL/min. This patient is most likely being treated with which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is a biguanide, which reduces both insulin resistance and liver production of glucose, and may thus indirectly decrease glucose clearance. It has no direct effect on renal glucose clearance and is not associated with glycosuria. Instead, adverse effects include lactic acidosis, weight loss, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Canagliflozin is an inhibitor of sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2). In healthy individuals, glucose is reabsorbed by SGLT-2 in the proximal tubules and the glucose clearance is 0 mL/min. In a diabetic patient with hyperglycemia, SGLT-2 becomes saturated and excess glucose is excreted in the urine so that the glucose clearance is > 0 mL/min but less than the GFR. If SGLT-2 is inhibited (as with canagliflozin), none of the glucose is reabsorbed. Instead, glucose is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, making it much like inulin, the substance used to estimate GFR. In this case, glucose clearance would approach the value of the GFR.

The glycosuria caused by SGLT-2 inhibitors puts patients at risk of both polyuria (from the osmotic effect of glucose) and urinary tract infections.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

C) INCORRECT:

Ifosfamide is an alkylating agent used as chemotherapy for many solid tumors and leukemias. It has a possible adverse effect of Fanconi syndrome, which causes impairment of proximal tubular reabsorption. Although Fanconi syndrome may lead to some degree of glycosuria, it does not involve complete inhibition of glucose reabsorption, meaning its glycosuria would not be as pronounced as in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Glipizide is a sulfonylurea, which is a category of drugs that block ATP-sensitive potassium channels of pancreatic β-cells and trigger insulin secretion. Sulfonylureas have no direct effect on renal glucose clearance. Instead, they are associated with the adverse effect of hypoglycemia – not glycosuria as in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, meaning it inhibits the enzyme that breaks down the incretin GLP-1. It enhances the incretin effects of increased insulin secretion, decreased glucagon secretion, and delayed gastric emptying. Linagliptin is contraindicated in renal failure because of its own renal clearance, but it has no direct effect on renal glucose clearance.

F) INCORRECT:

Acarbose is an α-glucosidase inhibitor, which reduces intestinal absorption of glucose from carbohydrates. Although acarbose is renally cleared and thus contraindicated in severe renal failure, it does not have a direct effect on the renal clearance of glucose. Instead, adverse effects include diarrhea and increased risk of hepatitis – not glycosuria as in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's glucose clearance is approaching the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), suggesting that there is almost no renal reabsorption of filtrated glucose.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His only medication is metformin. He has tried to lose weight for several years without success. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (243 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. His hemoglobin A1c is 8.5%. Which of the following is the most appropriate antidiabetic drug to address both this patient's glucose control and weight?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Miglitol, an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, is not associated with weight loss and is therefore not the most appropriate medication for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Glipizide is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs known to cause weight gain. Moreover, the use of sulfonylureas with biguanides such as metformin is associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemia, especially in patients older than 65 years.

C) CORRECT:

Liraglutide, which is a GLP-1 agonist, can facilitate weight loss and improve glycemic control. Incretin-based therapeutic agents such as GLP-1 agonists also have the additional benefit of carrying only a low risk of medication-induced hypoglycemia. Besides metformin and GLP-1 agonists, other drugs that can be used for weight loss in diabetic patients include SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin), orlistat, and pramlintide. However, orlistat does not cause glycemic control, which is desired in this patient, and pramlintide is only used in combination with insulin therapy.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

D) INCORRECT:

Nateglinide, a meglitinide, is associated with weight gain and is therefore not the most appropriate medication for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione and is known to cause weight gain, both directly and indirectly due to fluid retention and edema. It would therefore not be appropriate in this patient. Rosiglitazone's use in the US decreased dramatically after studies showed it was associated with an increased risk of heart attack and death. Subsequent studies have called this link into question.

F) INCORRECT:

Sitagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, can be used as an adjunct to metformin in patients with poor glycemic control. However, it does not facilitate weight loss. In addition, the capacity of DPP-4 inhibitors to lower glucose is not as great as some of the other classes of antidiabetic medications.
questions.hint: The most appropriate drug for this patient belongs to the class of glucagon-like peptide-1 analogs. These drugs promote weight loss, likely by delaying gastric emptying in response to food intake.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man is admitted to the hospital due to acute decompensated heart failure. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and heart failure. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, metformin, and low-dose aspirin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 105/min and regular, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 103/64 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.7 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8200/mm3



Serum



Na+

128 mEq/L


Cl-

98 mEq/L


K+

4.9 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
58 mg/dL


Glucose
200 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Which of the following changes in the medication regimen is most appropriate in this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are used to treat fluid congestion in patients with acute decompensated heart failure. However, loop diuretics are the first-line therapy while thiazide diuretics are used as an add-on if loop diuretics fail to relieve congestion.

B) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is commonly used in the empiric treatment of suspected MRSA infections. However, in the absence of fever and leukocytosis, this patient's respiratory symptoms are more consistent with pulmonary edema secondary to acutely decompensated heart failure than an infectious etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient takes aspirin for his coronary artery disease, which requires low-dose aspirin. While NSAIDs and high-dose aspirin are potentially nephrotoxic agents that should be avoided in patients with AKI, low-dose aspirin does not impair renal perfusion and should therefore be continued in this patient to prevent complications of his illness.

D) CORRECT:

Metformin is associated with an increased risk of life-threatening lactic acidosis in patients with conditions that reduce lactic acid clearance (i.e., renal and/or hepatic insufficiency), increase lactic acid production (e.g., sepsis), or a combination of both (e.g., acute decompensated heart failure). This patient's renal insufficiency and acute decompensated heart failure increase the risk of developing metformin-associated lactic acidosis; therefore, metformin should be discontinued. Insulin should be used instead of metformin for inpatient glycemic control.

E) INCORRECT:

The indications for vasodilator therapy in acute heart failure are acute heart failure due to a hypertensive emergency, flash pulmonary edema (which most commonly occurs in patients with acutely elevated blood pressure), and as an adjuvant to diuretics for symptomatic relief of dyspnea. As this patient's blood pressure is normal and they have not yet started diuretic therapy, vasodilator therapy is not required at this point.

F) INCORRECT:

Hemodynamic support with vasopressor therapy (e.g., norepinephrine) should be considered in patients with acute decompensated heart failure and cardiogenic shock refractory to inotropic therapy. As there is no evidence of cardiogenic shock (e.g., systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg), hemodynamic support is not required for this patient at this point.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory findings suggest prerenal acute kidney injury (BUN:creatinine ratio > 20:1) secondary to decompensated heart failure (cardiorenal syndrome).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the physician for a routine examination. Current medications include metformin and captopril. His pulse is 84/min and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 9.5%. The physician adds repaglinide to his treatment regimen. The mechanism of action of this agent is most similar to that of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unlike repaglinide, linagliptin increases the level of GLP-1 by inhibiting DPP-4, which promotes glucose-dependent insulin secretion. Adverse effects of linagliptin include gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation), headache, and pancreatitis.

B) CORRECT:

Glyburide is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion by closing ATP-sensitive potassium channels on beta cells of the pancreas. Its mechanism of action is, therefore, most similar to that of repaglinide. The most common adverse effect of glyburide is hypoglycemia.
Image Description:

- Biguanides (e.g., metformin): inhibit mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD) → reduction in hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipogenesis
- SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin): inhibit SGLT2 transport molecules in the kidney → reduced reabsorption of glucose from the renal filtrate
- α-Glucosidase inhibitors (e.g., acarbose): inhibit glycoside hydrolase enzymes, which are required to break down carbohydrate molecules in the gastrointestinal tract
- Thiazolidinediones (TZDs; e.g., pioglitazone): stimulate the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG) → transcription of genes responsible for glucose and lipid metabolism
- Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) and sulfonylurea analogs (e.g., repaglinide): inhibit ATP-dependent potassium channels → cell depolarization and the influx of calcium ions. The increased intracellular calcium stimulates insulin secretion from the pancreas.
- Incretin mimetics/GLP-1 receptor agonists (exenatide): bind to GLP-1 receptors and are resistant to degradation by DPP-4 enzyme → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, slow gastric emptying
- DPP-4 inhibitors/gliptins (e.g., sitagliptin): indirectly increase the endogenous incretin effect by inhibiting DPP-4 enzyme that breaks down GLP-1 → ↑ insulin secretion, ↓ glucagon secretion, delayed gastric emptying

C) INCORRECT:

Unlike repaglinide, metformin acts by decreasing hepatic gluconeogenesis and increasing insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues. Adverse effects of metformin include nausea, diarrhea, and lactic acidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Unlike repaglinide, dapagliflozin blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron causing increased urinary excretion of glucose. Adverse effects of dapagliflozin include vulvovaginal candidiasis, urinary tract infection, and hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

Unlike repaglinide, pioglitazone acts by activating PPAR-γ, which results in improved tissue insulin sensitivity and decreased hepatic gluconeogenesis. Adverse effects of pioglitazone include weight gain, heart failure, and osteoporosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Unlike repaglinide, miglitol prevents the hydrolysis of polysaccharides to monosaccharides. As a result, absorption of glucose in the intestine is reduced. Adverse effects of miglitol include flatulence, diarrhea, and early satiety.
questions.hint: Meglitinides such as repaglinide increase insulin secretion by closing ATP-sensitive potassium channels on the beta cells of the pancreas.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a 10-year history of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension presents for routine follow-up. His medications include aspirin 81 mg daily, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, amlodipine 10 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and atorvastatin 40 mg daily.
On examination, his height is 188 cm and his weight is 120 kg (BMI, 34). Funduscopic examination reveals cotton-wool spots. His heart and lung examinations are normal. Monofilament examination shows bilateral diminished sensation over his forefeet; vibratory sensation in his feet is intact. He has mild, long-standing peripheral edema in the legs, attributed to chronic venous insufficiency.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a glycated hemoglobin level of 7.5% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
When you discuss possible medication options with the patient, he mentions that he cannot continue in his occupation as a school bus driver if he takes medications that put him at risk for hypoglycemia.
Which one of the following medications is LEAST likely to cause hypoglycemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insulin, meglitinides (e.g., repaglinide), and sulfonylureas (e.g., glipizide and glimepiride) can directly cause hypoglycemia and are all associated with weight gain.

B) INCORRECT:

Insulin, meglitinides (e.g., repaglinide), and sulfonylureas (e.g., glipizide and glimepiride) can directly cause hypoglycemia and are all associated with weight gain.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulin, meglitinides (e.g., repaglinide), and sulfonylureas (e.g., glipizide and glimepiride) can directly cause hypoglycemia and are all associated with weight gain.

D) INCORRECT:

Insulin, meglitinides (e.g., repaglinide), and sulfonylureas (e.g., glipizide and glimepiride) can directly cause hypoglycemia and are all associated with weight gain.

E) CORRECT:

Avoiding hypoglycemia is generally important in diabetes treatment, but it is especially so in patients whose occupations make them responsible for the safety of other people (as in this patient who drives a bus or others who operate dangerous machinery). Another consideration in this patient is his obesity. Some diabetes medications are associated with weight gain and should ideally be avoided in this patient.

Dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP)-4 inhibitors, such as sitagliptin, are a class of oral diabetes medications that are not associated with weight gain and that generally do not cause hypoglycemia if administered as monotherapy, although they can when used in combination with sulfonylureas or insulin.

DPP-4 inhibitors generally lower glycosylated hemoglobin levels modestly, by 0.5 to 0.8%. These agents are not frequently used because they are expensive and lack long-term data on important clinical outcomes. However, a DPP-4 inhibitor would be a reasonable option in this patient with mild hyperglycemia in whom avoiding hypoglycemia is important; it also has the added benefit of not contributing further to the patient’s obesity.

Other options that would not directly cause hypoglycemia and that are also often associated with weight loss include:

• Injectable glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists, such as exenatide, liraglutide, semaglutide, and dulaglutide
• Dual agonists of the receptors for GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (such as tirzepatide)
• Sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors, such as empagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and canagliflozin

Key learning point: The main classes of diabetes medications that do not cause hypoglycemia are the biguanides (such as metformin), the sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors, the glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists, the dual agonists of the receptors for GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (such as tirzepatide), the thiazolidinediones (such as pioglitazone), and the dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (such as sitagliptin).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to discuss his uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and obesity (BMI, 33). Since his diabetes diagnosis one year ago, he has taken metformin 1000 mg twice daily and joined a formal weight-loss program, but he has not had any significant weight loss and his most recent glycated hemoglobin level was 7.6%. He is concerned about the long-term risks of uncontrolled hyperglycemia and is therefore motivated to add another antidiabetic agent. He also wants to discuss medications to help him lose weight.
Which one of the following medications would be most effective in helping this patient achieve his dual goals of improving glycemic control and losing weight?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glipizide, which is a sulfonylurea, causes increased insulin release from beta cells. Although sulfonylureas can be effective in lowering blood glucose, they often cause weight gain.

B) CORRECT:

Semaglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that is approved for two separate indications and is formulated and dosed accordingly as shown in the table below.

In a study comparing the 1-mg dose of semaglutide with the 2.4-mg dose among people with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥27, the average loss of body weight at 68 weeks was 7% with the 1-mg dose and 9.6% with the 2.4-mg dose. Other trials of the 2.4-mg dose have shown an average weight loss of 14% to 17% among individuals with or without diabetes.

Another GLP-1 receptor agonist, liraglutide, is also approved for both type 2 diabetes and weight loss but as daily rather than weekly injections. The weight loss seen with this agent, at the higher dose used for weight loss, is around 6.4% over 68 weeks.

Given its positive effects on both glycemic control and obesity, a GLP-1 receptor agonist such as semaglutide is a good choice for this patient.

More recently, tirzepatide, a dual agonist of the GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide receptors, has been approved for the management of hyperglycemia in patients with type 2 diabetes. This agent has been associated with even greater weight loss than semaglutide, with one head-to-head trial showing an average weight loss of 13.1% over 40 weeks with the highest dose of tirzepatide compared with 6.7% with the 1-mg dose of semaglutide. Tirzepatide would therefore also be a reasonable option in this patient, although it has not yet been shown to have the range of nonglycemic, nonweight benefits, such as cardiovascular risk reduction, that is seen with the GLP-1 receptor agonists.

A sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor might also be a good option, as these oral agents are associated with an average weight loss of 3 kg over 12 weeks. Medication options that are weight-loss neutral, such as dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, are also available.

Key learning point: The classes of antidiabetic medications associated with the greatest weight-loss benefit are the glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists and the dual agonists of the GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide receptors.

C) INCORRECT:

Glimepiride, which is a sulfonylurea, causes increased insulin release from beta cells. Although sulfonylureas can be effective in lowering blood glucose, they often cause weight gain.

D) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone is in the thiazolidinedione class of antidiabetic medications, which can cause weight gain due to fluid retention and an increase in subcutaneous adipose tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Repaglinide, an antidiabetic agent in the meglitinide class, stimulates the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells and would not be expected to cause weight loss.

Since his diabetes diagnosis one year ago, he has taken metformin 1000 mg twice daily and joined a formal weight-loss program, but he has not had any significant weight loss and his most recent glycated hemoglobin level was 7.6%.
